_desc.NAICS_DESCRIPTION: Mayonnaise, Dressing, and Other Prepared Sauce Manufacturing

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
1.0 Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies:  The Kraft Foods NA-Garland, TX 

facility has an excellent record of release prevention for its anhydrous ammonia 

refrigeration process (AARP).  The facility has a thorough emergency training program for 

on-site emergency responders and a complete preventative maintenance program as part of a 

Computerized Maintenance Management System.  The emergency response policies at the facility 

ensure that there is emergency response coverage 24 hours per day, 7 days per week.  There 

are also adequate provisions for coordination with outside agencies, such as the Garland 

Fire Department, in the event of an emergency.  

2.0 Process Description and Regulated Substances:  Kraft manufactures salad dressings, 

barbecue sauces, and ready-to-drink beverages at the facility.  The facility NCICS code is 

311941, "Mayonnaise, Dressing, and other Prepared Sauce manufacturing".  The facility 

produces and packages dressings, barbecue sauces, and ready-to-drink beverages for consumer 

consumption.  The storage and process areas of the facility are, therefore, refrigerated to 

preserve the products.  Kraft has one 40 CFR 68 (RMP Rule) regulated substance at the 

facility - anhydrous ammonia (ammonia).  Ammonia is used at the facility to refrigerate raw 

materials and finished food products and to provide climate control.  The threshold quantity 

for regulation of ammonia under 40 CFR 68 is 10,000 pounds.  The facility stores and uses 

38,000 pounds of ammonia and is, therefore, subject to the requirements of the RMP Rule.  
3.0 General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps: 

Ammonia falls under Program 3 of the RMP Rule, which is identical to the OSHA Process Safety 

management (PSM) program.  Kraft has developed a compliant PSM program for the ammonia 

system at the facility, and is, therefore, also in compliance with the Program 3 

requirements.  There are several ke

y aspects of the PSM program:  (1) Utility personnel are 

present on site and assigned to the ammonia system 24 hours per day, 7 days per week, (2) 

The facility maintains good training, certification, and employee awareness of operating 

procedures, (3) The facility has an aggressive PSM meeting schedule, and (4) Changes to the 

ammonia system are controlled under the Change Management Process.  

4.0 Five-year Accident History:  There have been no reportable accidental releases of 

ammonia, as defined by 40 CFR 68.42(a), at the facility in the last ten years.  

5.0 Emergency Response Program: Kraft has instituted an Emergency Response Plan for the 

facility that divides employees into various management and response teams.  There are 25 

in-plant contacts for emergency response which are listed in the Plan.  There are also 

back-up personnel available in the event that the primary incident response personnel are 

not available.  At the discretion of the Incident Commander, the Garland Fire Department 

(GFD) will be called to provide additional emergency responders and equipment.  For all fire 

emergencies, GFD will be summoned.  In addition, an ambulance always responds with GFD by 

city policy.  The plan includes information about the frequency and content of employee 

emergency response training.  Most importantly, the plan contains specific procedures to be 

followed in the event of a fire or other ammonia emergency.  These include:  (1) response to 

an accidental discharge of hazardous materials or waste (2) notification of internal, 

external, and regulatory agencies, (3) accident prevention measures, (4) procedures to 

contain and limit the duration of an emergency, (5) countermeasures to be employed during an 

emergency, (6) procedures to protect emergency responders and other employees.  The plan 

also incorporates the facility Spill Prevention, Control, and Countermeasures (SPCC) plan by 

reference.  The SPCC plan includes the locatio

n, types, and amounts of oil and chemicals 

stored on site and details the notification and countermeasure procedures to be followed in 

the even of a spill.  

6. Planned Changes to Improve Safety:  As a result of periodic reviews of the ammonia 

process hazard analysis (PHA) required by the RMP Rule and the PSM program, a number of 

process improvements have been implemented in the last 10 years.  The most recent example is 

the addition of an automatic ammonia sensing and shut-off system for the boiler room to be 

completed in the second quarter of 2004.
